BE11:03am

This Court has already concluded that the Prime Minister’s advice to Her Majesty was unlawful, void and of no effect. This means that the Order in Council to which it led was also unlawful, void and of no effect and should be quashed. This means that when the Royal Commissioners walked into the House of Lords it was as if they walked in with a blank sheet of paper. The prorogation was also void and of no effect. Parliament has not been prorogued. This is the unanimous judgment of all 11 Justices.

It is for Parliament, and in particular the Speaker and the Lord Speaker to decide what to do next. Unless there is some Parliamentary rule of which we are unaware, they can take immediate steps to enable each House to meet as soon as possible. It is not clear to us that any step is needed from the Prime Minister, but if it is, the court is pleased that his counsel have told the court that he will take all necessary steps to comply with the terms of any declaration made by this court.

BE11:18am

[T]he drag from MREL funding costs is a key driver of our earnings estimates, 35% below Refinitiv consensus 2020 PBT (albeit today’s aborted bond issue at 7.5% was at an even higher cost than we had factored in).

Metro Bank had hoped for funding spreads to narrow following its £375m equity raise in May and potentially issuance of a supportive credit rating (note Fitch Long Term at BB+, below investment grade). However, this has not been the case, with the yield on its sole outstanding £250m Tier 2 note currently trading with an implied yield (to maturity) of c8-9%; hence, today’s issuance coupon was likely insufficient for investors.

BE11:19am

So what next?

BE11:19am

The postponement raises questions on what Metro Bank may look to do next:

· Metro may hope for a normalisation in funding market conditions and issue in a more favourable backdrop before year-end. However, this is clearly subject to Brexit-driven volatility, with political headline risk likely to remain elevated into 31st October, and a shrinking issuance window thereafter.

· Metro returns offer an even higher coupon in the hope of increasing investor interest. This, however, presents a further substantial headwind to earnings; we estimate each additional 1% to the cost of c£200m MREL would take c10% off 2019e statutory PBT.

· Metro may seek to miss its interim MREL requirement – or hope for regulatory forbearance on the matter, although it’s unclear to us at this moment the consequence/likelihood of any such an actions.

Claus in Copenhagen @2s10s Let's not make this kind of thing a habit (impressed by the SC procedings, btw, lots of clear thinking, with a little bit of muck).
alewis2005 this was while appearing on tv as the voice of the industry
2s10s @Nightingale: ta
Viking1 Claus , any sign of the missing Danske ex ceo ?
Forester @alewis you had dinner with her? At her gaff?!
11:20 am
BE11:20am

And of course, this is just cladding for Metro. It doesn't really improve the business or anything like that.

BE11:20am

Almost regardless of whether Metro Bank can issue, we think it raises questions on Metro Bank’s ability to grow. Based on Q2 pro-forma RWAs of £9.3bn (adjusted for the £521m mortgage book sale), Metro’s total capital % RWAs stood at 18.8% and it would need to issue c£250m MREL in order to almost exactly hit its interim MREL requirement of 21.5%. However, this would have left little room for balance sheet growth in 2020, which is needed to deliver on the company’s growth agenda and drive operating leverage improvements to rebuild the RoTE (BARCe 2% 2020, vs. 1% in 2019).

nightingale20201 @2/10...BTW, Fitch has Metro on a Negative Rating Watch
BE11:21am

With little scope to grow, we think it makes sense to dispose of assets to free up capital and reduce its MREL requirement. ... Metro Bank could potentially boost its CET1 ratio by c300bp by selling what we see as £1.7bn of effectively ‘non-core’ assets which are uneconomic for Metro Bank to hold as they are now risk-weighted at 100%. However, this would depend on Metro being able to sell the assets at book value, which we would see as an uncertain outcome and likely incur a substantial loss of earnings (albeit would be returns enhancing).

11:21 am
BE11:21am

They remain sellers, in case you didn't guess.

BE11:21am

Despite share price -84% YTD, Metro Bank is not cheap at c17x 2020e earnings or 0.3x 2019 TNAV for a 1-2% RoTE.

Ultimately Metro does have a little wiggle room left from a timing perspective ....

BE11:24am

.... and if it feels that bond spreads in the UK market right now aren't favorable, this action could end up being prudent in attempting to limit the overall firm's cost of capital.

Claus in Copenhagen @Mouselet, and I was brought up to see banking as dull.....
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Having said that, it is a very tight window the bank finds itself in here, needing to raise between £250-500mm of MREL qualified debt by January 1, 2020, depending on the bank's growth and asset levels achieved during this time period. The reaction in the shares (-5%) is understandable, as the bank's leverage in this process would seem to be shrinking as it allows the deadline to get closer and closer. Ultimately, we believe it will be difficult for Metro's shares to show any positive momentum until the market has better clarity and confidence in the capital plan moving forward, in addition to the potential for any financial fines from its regulator as a result of the RWA miscalculation earlier this year.

Mouselet It's a *bank*. 'has a little wiggle room left from a timing perspective' is a reasonable thing to read about a medium manufacturer, banks should never need to wiggle

Tui AG (TUI:LSE): Last: 939.20, up 37.8 (+4.19%), High: 949.20, Low: 898.40, Volume: 1.28m

BE11:33am

But Karstadt, majority shareholder of Thomas Cook to remind, was the driver behind the merger. It was the reason Thomas Cook did a share buyback shortly after backing into an effectively bankrupt business.

2s10s Tui were loss-making quite recently as well.

Soundbuy Dart Grp - you get Fowler Welch strapped on for the ride too....
11:35 am
JP11:35am

(Full disclosure: family member used to work for TUI. In case anyone cares.)

BE11:35am

Then, of course, Karstadt changed its name to Arcandor and collapsed.

BE11:36am

Why this bit of the story doesn't get mentioned in the obits, I don't know. Great British Name Brought Down by Germans!

11:35 am
BE11:36am

(Albeit it took a decade.)

BE11:36am

Anyway, Tui.

BE11:36am

FY19 is closing out as expected and FY20 outlook is suitably cautious. Today's update serves to highlight what a different business TUI has become: hotel and cruise assets generate strong and stable cash flows and the capital structure is fit to manage the working capital strains that ultimately did for its onetime peer Thomas Cook. How much TUI benefits from TC's demise will depend on how capacity gets redeployed. Precedent dictates not to get too hopeful, but we would be surprised if there wasn't at least some resulting capacity consolidation and relief for the sector. Buy with 12% FCF yield.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

This is Stifel.

BE11:37am

FY19 closing out much as expected. As per Q3 guidance TUI expects underlying EBITA to be down c.€300m on last year's base of €1,177m (Stifel €857m) reflecting €300m of one-off disruption costs from MAX 737 aircraft grounding. FX translation impact of +€11m (was +€15m). We forecast net debt of €1.3bn (final year of peak capex) equating to 3.5x gross leverage, temporarily above TUI's target range of 2.25-3x.

Hotels & Resorts performance reflects demand shifting from Western to Eastern Med, with demand for Spain normalising. 70 new hotels will have been added since the merger and TUI Blue will become the flagship hotel brand, allowing for asset-light growth, targeting ~100 hotels by the end of 2020 (from 10 now). In Cruises the new TUI Cruises Mein Schiff 2, Marella Explorer 2 and Hanseatic nature showed high occupancy levels and robust daily rates despite a significant increase in German market capacity. Markets & Airlines performance was marred by 737 MAX aircraft grounding but the most recent trading weeks have, as anticipated, been stronger in both bookings (flat, was -1%) and pricing (+1% unchanged).

The FY20 profit rebound will depend in part on the MAX recovery profile, still pending FAA and EASA approval. TUI anticipate a smaller level of aircraft replacement costs compared to Summer 2019. We assume a residual headwind of €50m and that aircraft are cleared to fly for Summer 2020. Outlook commentary is suitably cautious with the winter programme one third sold. The weaker demand environment persists and has led TUI to reduce capacity by 2% with bookings in-line and pricing +4%.

Mouselet Quite a small bag on the side, though probably exporting peas from Lincolnshire isn't the most promising business in the near future
BE11:37am

...and in part on how the dust settles post Thomas Cook's collapse. Most important is how capacity gets redeployed. TC accounted for about 2.5% of UK-Europe seat capacity and 1.5% of intra-Europe capacity which, if it was all to be removed, would provide significant relief from the overcapacity facing incumbent operators like TUI. The precedent from smaller failures (Monarch, Air Berlin) is that capacity largely gets backfilled by new operators. But TC is far larger and previous attempt to save the business would suggest that a piecemeal breakup is most likely, with a range of companies potentially interested in cherry picking airport slots. We expect this to take time and would be surprised if there wasn't at least some resulting capacity consolidation, with a benefit to TUI. We currently forecast €1,139m underlying EBITA in FY20, similar to the FY18 outcome, but given TUI's outlook commentary there may be little bit of downward pressure on consensus.

Stifel view. Business models across the travel spectrum are being tested by macro and industry headwinds. We feel TUI has the right set up and outlook, focused on digital and platform initiatives, to be a long-term winner - with barriers to entry. Having navigated a capex hump enabling its transition from a traditional tour operator to an integrated tourism group, TUI now generates 75% of profits from hotel, cruise and destination content (FY20E EBITA). TUI’s cash flow profile is approaching inflection. Our FCF estimates yield 12% in FY20 and FY21, underpinning a dividend yield of 7%. We think a less mechanical dividend policy would be taken well by the market given the DPS 'cut' resulting from the MAX fallout this year. TUI is well placed and prepared to participate in industry consolidation. Our pragmatic SOTP valuation points to a fair value of 940p and we reiterate our Buy rating.

11:37 am
JP11:37am

FCF yield of of 12% is pretty damn tasty.

JP11:37am

If I may say so myself.

JP11:38am

I got UBS here, saying "less competition is good":

11:37 am
JP11:38am

Thomas Cook liquidation – tailwind to sentiment and short term profits
We upgrade TUI to Neutral to reflect our expectations for improvement in short term profitability and free cash flow driven by the entry of Thomas Cook into compulsory liquidation. We raise our EPS estimates by 7%/23% in FY19/20 but only moderately increase FY21 by +2%. However, after the ~7% price increase yesterday we think the share price seems to reflect a good part of these positive effects. Furthermore, we are less convinced about the mid-term benefits of the market consolidation. We expect in the context of low entry barriers incremental capacity to come to the market over the next 12-24 months. We therefore assume the recovery in profitability will be short-lived before pressure on tour operator margins could re-emerge.

JP11:38am

Declining consumer confidence an element of uncertainty for FY20e
TUI tour operator EBIT margins have been historically driven by the changes in capacity, consumer confidence and FX (Figure 2, Figure 5). We illustrate that UK consumer confidence is slightly below its 15 years average while German consumer confidence is above its long term average. Potential further meaningful pressure on consumer confidence may represent a headwind in FY20 for tour operator and cruise demand.
Fewer benefits vs. prior consolidations; potentially more stringent regulation
Vs. 2007 UK tour operator consolidation (280bps EBIT margin improvement) we expect more moderate and shorter duration margin improvement today to reflect click here: i) a higher market fragmentation vs. past; ii) higher online distribution – today over 60% (vs. 25% in 2007) representing a headwind to pricing discipline; iii) absence of synergies for TUI. In a scenario where the Civil Aviation Authority may consider applying more stringent regulation, this could lead to increased cash restrictions for the tour operators. We estimate TUI has ~£2bn in advance payments which are not considered restricted cash by most market participants.

JP11:38am

Valuation: increase SoTP-driven PT to 900p (prior PT 740p)
We raise our PT on the back of upgrades to our estimates in the tour operator business and a slightly higher multiple for the tour op 3x 2020 EV/EBITDA (vs. 2.5x prior) justified by lower perceived risk. TUI reports FY results mid-December.

2s10s Tui made a loss in Q4 17, Q1 18

11:42 am

Royal Mail's ongoing dispute with its workforce poses significant problems, even if industrial action going into the peak season can be avoided. The recent share price strength is at odds with the deteriorating industrial relations picture and weakening macro outlook, and the valuation wholly unreflective of the structural challenges faced by the group. We downgrade our recommendation to SELL from Hold, with an unchanged DCF-based TP of 185p.

2s10s @JP: good one

Which is in response to the Communication Workers Union sending out ballot papers last week.

Bluesky21 Royal Mail IPO'ed at 330p

The main gripe seems to be working week.

11:44 am
JP11:44am

Ballot papers today, decision next week.

BE11:44am

The most important issue in the current dispute is working hours. Prior to the current agreement, Royal Mail’s working week was 39 hours. A one-hour reduction to 38 hours from October 2018 was hard coded into the current agreement, and has been implemented. A softer commitment to a further onehour working week reduction from October 2019 was agreed, subject to the
successful trial of productivity initiatives that would offset the impact of fewer working hours. A long-term goal of reducing the working week to 35 hours by 2022 was agreed, but without a detailed timescale for implementation.
Royal Mail has an ongoing requirement to deliver annual productivity improvements to offset the ongoing annual inflation in its cost base, which is dominated by labour (c.70%)

BE11:49am

If the prorogation had not happened, Parliament would probably have been on Conference recess
now. Indeed, the PM is due to give his speech in Manchester on Wednesday 2 October - a day
when, if Parliament is sitting, he should in theory be answering prime minister's questions.

BE11:49am

But against the backdrop of the Judges' ruling, and with the Labour and Lib Dem conferences having
already taken place, the government may not try to hold that recess now (even if it is totally standard
procedure). Even if it wanted a short break to cover the Conservative Party conference (29 September - 2
October), recess requires a majority vote in Parliament - and that looks decidedly tricky for the
government at the moment.

11:48 am
JP11:49am

(@A.M. -- yep.)

Soundbuy Fowler Welch - reckon they'd come knocking on the door of Norish....
BE11:49am

So, it looks like Parliament will have around three more weeks ahead of 31 October than it thought
previously. What might MPs do with that time? For one thing, they might want to tighten up the Benn
legislation passed in early September ahead of the prorogation. As the FT reported on 18 September,
some MPs fear there is a loophole which could still allow a 'no deal' Brexit. The legislation requiring the
government to seek an extension of Article 50 does not apply if Parliament has voted in favour of leaving
with a deal by 19 October. But one possibility is that the government could obtain Parliamentary
approval for the deal, but not implement the full legislation by 31 October, meaning the UK ends up
leaving without a deal by default. Ex Conservative now Lib Dem MP Phillip Lee told the FT that
opposition MPs would amend the bill if necessary.

BE11:49am

Beyond agreeing that they do not want 'no deal' Brexit, though, the opposition look divided. The Lib
Dems want to revoke Article 50 without a referendum, while Labour want a referendum, but voted
yesterday to stay neutral in such a referendum. Many of the Conservative rebels who were expelled from
the party in September and now sit as independents want to leave the EU with a deal - and voted three
times in favour of Theresa May's deal. Some of the Labour party didn’t vote for the deal but now wish
they had. It is not at all clear that this disparate group of politicians can agree on a further course of
action from here.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Okay, so. A confidence vote?

BE11:50am

[T]o do so would risk sending the UK towards an early election, which would mean Parliament
was shut down again - possibly before any Article 50 extension was requested. Elections in the UK need
to happen at least five weeks after being called, during which time Parliament is dissolved. Five weeks
from this Thursday is 31 October 2019. The PM would still be required by the Benn bill to request the
extension, but MPs may still prefer to be sitting when the request is made. So, we suspect the opposition may not take the step of calling a no confidence vote at this point.

BE11:50am

Anti-'no deal' unity government?

cheeckychappy @BE - heard anymore around the Hong Kong bid for LSE. Surely worth a dig?
11:51 am
JP11:51am

I have no idea anymore. Does anyone?

BE11:51am

In such a scenario, the government would lose the vote of no confidence, triggering a two week period in which an opposition candidate would try to gain the confidence of the House. Such a unity government would then seek a Brexit extension and call an election. However, apart from the logistical difficulties of finding a candidate for PM that all opposition MPs can get behind - from rebel ex Conservatives to Corbyn-supporting Labour MPs - such a move could be quite contentious.

BE11:51am

There is also another, even more contentious possibility, which is that opposition MPs could seek to
make sure a 'no deal' Brexit is not allowed to happen in any circumstances - even after an election. In that
case, a unity government might try to stay on longer and do more - including possibly legislating to
permanently block a 'no deal' Brexit or hold a second referendum.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

So .............. uh, nothing? Probably?

BE11:52am

That scenario is possible, but contentious and complicated. So, despite the noise, it may be that the effect
of prorogation has already played out, regardless of the judges' decision. By forcing the opposition to act
quickly, the prorogation has already resulted in a significantly lower chance of 'no deal' Brexit. Even
though Parliament now has more time, opposition MPs have already done what they sought to do - and
the extra time does not really change that. Still, it may prove a major blow to the government in the
court of public opinion, and give ammunition to the opposition parties in any upcoming election
campaign.
